item.content:encoded:
Side Projectsâ€Šâ€”â€ŠStranger ThingsÂ Fanart

Subscribe to our half-monthly newsletter for regular side project inspiration.

Stranger Things is back with its new season and the internet is going gaga about it. Letâ€™s take you back in time when Eleven made her first appearance. Lyn-Hui Ong created a series of animated character posters as herÂ fanart.

Letâ€™s marvel atÂ it.

Lyn-Hui Ong is an Illustrator and Graphic Designer based in Penang, Malaysia. She also runs ForRealâ€Šâ€”â€Šan indie studio with her partner Kwok JinÂ Xin.

See the complete Stranger Things Fanart projectÂ here.

Check out her Behance to see more of her illustrations and follow her on Instagram for behind the scenes and personalÂ updates.

item.title: Why give back to the Community?
item.dc:creator: Darshan Gajara
item.content:encoded:
Product Prompt #29 on Product DisruptÂ Blog

Why give back to the community? Answering this question in a paragraph or two is going to be really difficult for me, Iâ€™ll try itÂ anyway.

We live in a shared world where everything (literally everything) is available at our fingertips. Whether one wants to learn to code or do magic tricks, itâ€™s all available on the world wide web for anyone and everyone toÂ learn.

This is because some nicer people decided to give with an open heart. In the process, they also encouraged others to do the same. And suddenly we had the plethora of knowledge on theÂ web.

We, as users, have always been taking so much from the community to grow in our respective careers but do we ever feel obliged to return it back? I do. I strongly believe in the concept of a community.

Giving back to the community is the only way to make the world a betterÂ place.

In order for a community to thrive, it needs to have members that donâ€™t just take from it but also fuelÂ it.

The idea of Product Disrupt also came to my mind as a way to facilitate young designers with the best of resources to help them learn product design. To this date, this hasnâ€™t changed a bit. Lately, Iâ€™ve been trying to figure out ways to keep this project running but the goals arenâ€™t changing in the near future. Itâ€™s always been about and for the community.

I also reached out to my mateâ€Šâ€”â€ŠArtiom, who has done a fair share of community work to know about his belief of giving back. Letâ€™s dive intoÂ it.

What has been always driving me is helpingÂ people.

Itâ€™s something that guides me for both commercial and non-commercial projects I build. When I founded a small boutique studio with my 2 partners several years ago, we defined our vision â€œto help people have a more creative, productive and healthy lifeâ€. When I think about it now, I think all three are still relevant to all I doÂ today.

Helping the community youâ€™re a part of is relatively easy because you understand really well their problems by experiencing them yourself or hearing others mentioning it. Also as a designer, you can use your skills to hack these solutions yourself.

Such an approach also had a positive side-effectâ€Šâ€”â€Šsince I was very involved in the design community and knew which struggles others are going through, it was easier for me to build commercial products like myÂ book.

Currently, Iâ€™m working on products that are targeting a non-tech audience and itâ€™s much more challenging since itâ€™s harder for me to empathize withÂ them.

â€“ Artiom Dashinsky

Related Interview: A Conversation with Artiom Dashinsky

Hit the clap ğŸ‘ icon if you enjoyed thisÂ story.

Why give back to the Community? was originally published in Product Disrupt Blog on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

item.content:encoded:
Side Projectsâ€Šâ€”â€ŠEpicÂ Spinners

Subscribe to our half-monthly newsletter for regular side project inspiration.

Vasili Savitski & Epicmax created a library of spinners using only CSS for your next web-based project. These are open source, easy to use and come with a VueJS integration.

Letâ€™s take a look at these epic spinners.

Epic Spinners are designed by Vasili Savitski and brought to life with code by Epicmax. Vasili is a freelance product designer and Epicmax is a web development agency both based inÂ Belarus.

Click here to get the Epic Spinners.

Make sure to check out Vasili Savitskiâ€™s work on his portfolio website and Epicmaxâ€™s work on epicmax.co.

item.title: How Important is Reading as a Creative Person?
item.dc:creator: Darshan Gajara
item.content:encoded:
Product Prompt #28 on Product DisruptÂ Blog

Iâ€™m an internet-made designer and I say this because I taught myself to design with the help of the internet.

There are loads of inspiring and kind folks out there who willingly share their experience through a blog, newsletter, videos, podcasts and moreâ€¦You just have to be looking and youâ€™ll find enough content to teach yourself to do anything, quite literally.

When I started out in design, I used to read at least 6â€“7 blogs to dive deeper in design and keep myself updated with the latest happenings in the tech industry. Over the years, that number has gone down but I still manage to read at least 3 stories on a workingÂ day.

Now there are numerous ways in which people can learn new things but reading works quite nicely for me and I canâ€™t recommend itÂ enough.

I also reached out to the design community to know their thoughts on reading. Letâ€™s also learn what they have toÂ say.

Reading is certainly a powerful way of gathering knowledge and insights from others, most importantly reading can expose us to diverse perspectives. But thatâ€™s only really true if you readÂ broadly.

If you read the same types of material on the same subject simply to confirm your perspective of the world it wonâ€™t do much in the way of adding fuel for creative thinking.

But this is true of most activities which expose you to new perspectives. Read if you find that enjoyable, yes, but you can also be creatively energized by traveling and talking to new people, picking up new and different hobbies, trying to learn almost anything new (programming, mechanical engineering, knitting, a new language, etc.).

Better yet: donâ€™t limit yourself to simply reading a lot, but indulge in diverse experiences and open yourself to opportunities in different ways to truly build up a creative reservoir.

â€“ Tanner Christensen

I started a challenge on the first day of this year to read a book every week. I was curious to see how my life would change by the end of the year. I didnâ€™t think much of it at first, only that it gave me a deadline to finish aÂ book.

Itâ€™s been 5 months and 21 books. Iâ€™m almost halfway through and I think the greatest thing that this challenge has taught me so far is allowing my brain to get more and more comfortable with the notion that itâ€™s okay to be uncomfortable. Even more than okay actuallyâ€Šâ€”â€Šinvigorating.

To be met, daily, with ideas, perspectives, viewpoints that I may have never been confronted by before carves a space in my mind to be lessÂ fearful.

For what is creativity anyway if not for the lack ofÂ fear?

â€“ NicoleÂ S.

Hit the clap ğŸ‘ icon if you enjoyed thisÂ story.

How Important is Reading as a Creative Person? was originally published in Product Disrupt Blog on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.
